required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of a Multi-tined Cannula Versus a Conventional Cannula for Cervical Medial Branch Radiofrequency Ablation in Chronic Neck Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of a Multi-tined Cannula Versus a Conventional Cannula for Cervical Medial Branch Radiofrequency Ablation in Chronic Neck Pain

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM)

clinical_study.source: Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM)

brief_summary.textblock: Chronic neck pain is a common disorder for spine specialists. Radiofrequency ablation of medial branches has been proven effective in selected patients for relieving pain. A newer radiofrequency ablation cannula has been developed (multi-tined), allowing perpendicular access. It is proposed as an alternative to the more technically challenging traditional approach. This study aims to compared the technical and clinical aspects of both techniques.

primary_outcome.measure: Numerical Pain Rating scale for patient's pain during the procedure
primary_outcome.description: pain during radiofrequency procedure will be compared between the 2 groups as a principal hypothesis is that the new multi-tined cannula is better tolerated by patients Scale is from 0-10, 0/10 is no pain which is better than pain of 10/10

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient pain (Numerical Rating Scale - NRS score)
secondary_outcome.description: therapeutic effect on pain Scale is from 0-10, 0/10 is no pain which is better than pain of 10/10
therapeutic effect on function scale is from 0-100%, where 0% is better than 100% in terms of the effect of pain on function

intervention.intervention_name: Radiofrequency ablation of cervical medial branches
intervention.description: Radiofrequency ablation of cervical medial branches

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or older
- Cervical neck pain at least 4/10 at rest or with activity
- Neck pain lasting at least 6 months and refractory to conservative treatments
- Neck pain is primarily axial (more than upper extremity)
- Success to medial branch block protocol
Exclusion Criteria:
- failure to medial branch block protocol (pain relief less than 75% on 2 occasions)
- Cervical neck pain less than 4/10
- Neurological deficits of upper extremity
- neuropathic pain of upper extremity
- pregnancy or breastfeeding
- inflammatory or neoplastic lesion on x-ray
- neck cortisone injection in last 3 months
- any medical or psychiatric condition contra-indicated for radiofrequency ablation
